issue.title: Replace `request` with the much ligther `got` module

repository.name: node-influx
repository.description: ðŸ“ˆ  The InfluxDB Client for Node.js and Browsers

issue.body:
WIP fix for #177 

All tests pass when debugging in WebStorm. 5 tests fail when running `npm test` - can someone help figure out why, maybe @ppannuto?

Also, we keep a `retries` key in our requestOptions, and `request()` didn't support a `retries` option. `got()` does have one such option.

repository.name: isomorphic-fetch
repository.description: Isomorphic WHATWG Fetch API, for Node & Browserify

issue.title: Replaced `request` with `node-fetch`

repository.name: node-influx
repository.description: ðŸ“ˆ  The InfluxDB Client for Node.js and Browsers

issue.body:
`node-tech` for use with isomorphic-fetch in browsers, instead of [`got`](https://github.com/node-influx/node-influx/pull/186).
- [x] Fix the [node-fetch issue with 204 no-content](https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/issues/165)
- [x] Fix last test - All tests pass, except the last hacky one. What exactly does the second "this" refer to in [the comment](https://github.com/node-influx/node-influx/blob/master/test.js#L742)?

issue.title: Add browser-based tests

repository.name: node-influx
repository.description: ðŸ“ˆ  The InfluxDB Client for Node.js and Browsers

issue.body:
...using Webpack and ideally jspm too, given #221, #225 and the like.

BTW, after guarding #225, Pool.json() dies with "Unexpected end of JSON input" when `res` is the empty string. While that sounds like the [bug I filed with node-fetch against handling 204 No Content results](https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/issues/165), a different error should be raised in that case because of this ([misleading](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=566239#c8)) XHR error:

> XMLHttpRequest cannot load http://localhost:8086/query?.... Credentials flag is 'true', but the 'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials' header is ''. It must be 'true' to allow credentials. Origin 'http://localhost:8080' is therefore not allowed access.

body: While I like the idea of an empty object as a JSON response, this moves away from the spec, as they've [consciously stayed with throwing an error](https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/113) - IMO it'd be better to stay with the spec for compatibility with native fetch implementations, but if not, should this at least be added as a known difference?
I agree. Plus, there's also the question whether we should return an empty object, or an empty string, or `0`, or `false`: all of which are legitimate JSON types. @bitinn, thoughts?

For me, the best thing is to stick with spec - an example use case I'm dealing with is running tests in JSDOM, but now the interface is different between a native client e.g. Chrome and the server side usage. The same applies to `isomorphic-fetch`, if it relies on this library, users will account for different responses based on if its a server or client environment, which essentially breaks the concept of isomorphic.

I am asking browser vendors for opinions in the same WHATWG thread. But status quo seems clear at this point, neither native implementation/browser fetch polyfill/spec handle 204 empty response.

We should revert our code to match their behaviour in `2.x` releases.
Thanks very much for the quick response - really appreciate your efforts on this, it's a great polyfill. Cheers!

issue.title: Return null for no-content responses with fetch

repository.name: feathers-rest
repository.description: The Feathers HTTP(S) transport plugin for REST APIs

issue.body: Checks if the response is 204 when using fetch and return `null` body. Fixes #83

repository.name: node-fetch
repository.description: A light-weight module that brings the Fetch API to Node.js

issue.title: Handle empty responses in `json`
issue.body:
Responses with status 204 and 205 don't contain a body which causes `response.json()` to blow up (unlike `response.text()` et al).

I _think_ the correct way to handle this is to return `null`.
